video.title: C++ Programming Course - Beginner to Advanced
video.description:
Learn modern C++ 20 programming in this comprehensive course.

💻 Source code: https://github.com/rutura/The-C-20-Masterclass-Source-Code

✏️ Course developed by Daniel Gakwaya. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCUYUFiuJ5XZ3JYtbq5dXRKQ
🐦 Twitter: https://twitter.com/learnqtguide
🔗 Want more from Daniel? https://www.learnqt.guide/udemy-discounted-9/
🔗 Join Daniel's discord server for support: https://discord.com/invite/PcATcraESW

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐
(0:00:00) Introduction

(0:04:32) Chapter 1: Setting up the tools
Tools
Installing C++ Compilers on Windows
Installing VS Code on Windows
Configuring Visual Studio Code for C++ on Windows
Installing C++ Compilers on Linux
Installing Visual Studio Code on Linux
Configuring Visual Studio Code for C++ on Linux
Installing C++ Compilers on MacOs
Installing Visual Studio Code on MacOs
Configuring Visual Studio Code for C++ on MacOs
Online Compilers

(1:43:01) Chapter 2: Diving in
Your First C++ Program
Comments
Errors and Warnings
Statements and Functions
Data input and output
C++ Program Execution Model
C++ core language Vs Standard library Vs STL

(3:00:47) Chapter 3: Variables and data types
Variables and data types Introduction
Number Systems
Integer types : Decimals and Integers
Integer Modifiers
Fractional Numbers
Booleans
Characters And Text
Auto
Assignments
Variables and data types summary

(4:46:46) Chapter 4: Operations on Data
Introduction on Data operations
Basic Operations
Precedence and Associativity
Prefix/Postfix Increment & Decrement
Compound Assignment Operators
Relational Operators
Logical Operators
Output formatting
Numeric Limits
Math Functions
Weird Integral Types
Data Operations Summary

(7:01:58) Chapter 5: Flow Control
Flow Control Introduction
If Statements
Else If
Switch
Ternary Operators
Flow Control Summary

(7:53:49) Chapter 6: Loops
Loops Introduction
For Loop
While Loop
Do While Loop

(8:47:08) Chapter 7: Arrays
Introduction to Arrays
Declaring and using arrays
Size of an array
Arrays of characters
Array Bounds

(9:53:23) Chapter 8: Pointers
Introduction to Pointers
Declaring and using pointers
Pointer to char
Program Memory Map Revisited
Dynamic Memory Allocation
Dangling Pointers
When new Fails
Null Pointer Safety
Memory Leaks
Dynamically allocated arrays

(12:11:04) Chapter 9: References
Introduction to References
Declaring and using references
Comparing pointers and references
References and const

(12:44:29) Chapter 10: Character Manipulation and Strings
Introduction to Strings
Character Manipulation
C-string manipulation
C-String concatenation and copy
Introducing std::string
Declaring and using std::string

(14:12:47) Chapter 11: Functions
The One Definition Rule
First Hand on C++ Functions
Function Declaration and Function Definitions
Multiple Files - Compilation Model Revisited
Pass by value
Pass by pointer
Pass by reference

(16:03:20) Chapter 12: Getting Things out of functions
Introduction to getting things out of functions
Input and output parameters
Returning from functions by value

(16:32:35) Chapter 13: Function Overloading
Function Overloading Introduction
Overloading with different parameters

(16:49:00) Chapter 14: Lambda functions
Intro to Lambda Functions
Declaring and using lambda functions
Capture lists
Capture all in context
Summary

(17:40:08) Chapter 15: Function Templates
Intro to function templates
Trying out function templates
Template type deduction and explicit arguments
Template parameters by reference
Template specialization

(19:04:31) Chapter 16: C++20 Concepts Crash course
Intro to C++20 Concepts
Using C++20 Concepts
Building your own C++20 Concepts
Zooming in on the requires clause
Combining C++20 Concepts
C++20 Concepts and auto

(20:15:40) Chapter 17: Classes
Intro to classes
Your First Class
C++ Constructors
Defaulted constructors
Setters and Getters
Class Across Multiple Files
Arrow pointer call notation
Destructors
Order of Constructor Destructor Calls
The this Pointer
struct
Size of objects

(22:52:43) Chapter 18: Inheritance
Introduction to Inheritance
First try on Inheritance
Protected members
Base class access specifiers : Zooming in
Closing in on Private Inheritance
Resurrecting Members Back in Context
Default Constructors with Inheritance
Custom Constructors With Inheritance
Copy Constructors with Inheritance
Inheriting Base Constructors
Inheritance and Destructors
Reused Symbols in Inheritance

(26:21:03) Chapter 19: Polymorphism
Introduction to Polymorphism
Static Binding with Inheritance
Dynamic binding with virtual functions
Size of polymorphic objects and slicing
Polymorphic objects stored in collections (array)
Override
Overloading, overriding and function hiding
Inheritance and Polymorphism at different levels
Inheritance and polymorphism with static members
Final
Virtual functions with default arguments
Virtual Destructors
Dynamic casts
Polymorphic Functions and Destructors
Pure virtual functions and abstract classes
Abstract Classes as Interfaces

topLevelComment.author: LearnQtGuide
topLevelComment.text:
Thanks so much for hosting our course . I've learnt so much from the channel myself! Knowing that even a single individual benefits from the course gives me great pleasure. 

If anyone has specific questions or just wants to hang out talking about tech or C++, consider joining the discord server shared in the description. Can't wait to see what you guys build with C++.

replies.author: Emerson Tavera
replies.text: Guys, I am a language teacher in Colombia, I discovered this thing called software development during the covid time, i found it amazing and so exciting, 2 years later I decided to change my career, I am 23 years old, and I already enrolled into a University for software engineering, I feel more comfortable being at the U so I won't get too deep into and why I just don't learn by myself. the point is that I decided to start with C++ and start learning things by myself, I want to learn more about blockchain development so based on my research I think C++ is the way to go, thanks guys for this full course, I will read many books along the way, and hopefully in 2 years I can get a job while still studying at the university. I AM SO FUC*ING AFRAID OF THIS CHANGE, but I just can´t live a life without knowing what would happen if I don't do this, so wish me luck. love u guys, thanks for the course once again

topLevelComment.author: Erik Vikner
topLevelComment.text:
Half way thru in just a week! I really recommend not even downloading the github and instead writing what you see since it will stick better, at least for me. Even if its repetative typing cout << enld; 5.000 times you will never forget it if you do it this way.

I could never read a single book without getting bored and forgetting everything i just read so this hands on course really works for me!

Meanwhile i found these exercises where you do practise programing that kind of matches your course. I really recommend this site if you are doing this course. Do as much as u can in exercises and stop when you cant manage to write a program without "looking for help". Its a great way to learn the basics of math equations as well wich is kind of fundamental. Since i have no previouse experience with math at this lever i really felt this helped me a lot to both read and write my own equations!

Exercises:
https://www.w3resource.com/cpp-exercises/basic/index.php

Thank you so much for this. I am forever grateful!

topLevelComment.author: Alex Go
topLevelComment.text:
14:16 windlibs
- Release Versions - UCRT runtime
- GCC Download
- Copy mingw64 folder to C:\mingw64
-- the system environment variables
--- System properties --> Advance tab --> Environment variables
---- System variables --> path --> edit --> new --> browse --> C:\mingw64\bin

Visual studio code
31:20 Terminal Tasks (link c++ compiler to VSC)
32:21 - Visual Studio Code --> Terminal --> Configure Tasks --> C/C++:g++.exe build active file
34:54 - [To enable C++20 support, add the command-line parameter]
in "args" add "-std=c++20", (setting up c++ version to compile in tasks.json)
40:22 - in "args" --- replace "args" configuration below for the purpose of this course.
        "-g",
        "-std=c++20",
        "${workspaceFolder}\\*.cpp",
        "-o",
        "${fileDirname}\\rooster.exe"
41:58 the end of GCC compiler connected to VSC anc connect CLANG compiler to VSC
-- Just change the label name in CLANG Build with Clang 14.0.6 
-- and copy GCC's args configuration to CLANG's args
45:21 compiler from microsoft
57:07 Install compiler on Linux

topLevelComment.author: Simeon Lyts
topLevelComment.text:
I've finally finished this course! It took me 1 full week to do it. Overall, I want to thank the author for providing such a nice learning material for free. I've learnt a lot from this course. The only issue I had while watching this video, is that I thought it is a full step-by-step tutorial, but  it's not. There were quite a few moments, when it feels like something happened between one lesson and the other. The author suddenly used a std::ostream function, which let us send our objects directly to 'cout' after defining it in the class, and said something like "We've already learned about this in one of the previous lesson". But apparently, this lesson wasn't included in this video. I spent quite a lot of time figuring out how it works on my own.
Apart from that, this video was super helpful, and it definitely deserves my 'like' !

topLevelComment.author: Andrew Win
topLevelComment.text:
At 1:43:15 you open a Developer PowerShell for VS 2019 which has this line:

PS C:\VisualStudioCode\Microsoft VS Code>

But when I open this PowerShell on my computer I get the line:

PS C:\Users\...\source\repos>

When I type .\Code.exe , I get the message:

.\Code.exe : The term '.\Code.exe' is not recognized as the name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or operable
program. Check the spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.
At line:1 char:1
+ .\Code.exe
+ ~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : ObjectNotFound: (.\Code.exe:String) [], CommandNotFoundException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : CommandNotFoundException


How can I fix this, and should I change Visual Studio to another location than C:\Users\...\source\repos ? If so, how do I change location?

replies.author: Andrew Win
replies.text: @Sixten Tamleht  Tnx for answering, appreciate it  :) :)  Not sure if I understood your answer though, but I had to reinstall Windows 10 because my PowerShell was corrupted, and I got it to work (somehow) after reinstalling, so I guess and hope that the problem is solved. It is for now at least.

replies.author: Sixten Tamleht
replies.text:
make sure you are in the right directory when you try to run.
example: 
if you save your file in C:\Users\admin\Desktop but in powershell it says C:\Users\...\source\repos  then you have to type cd C:\Users\admin\Desktop
(Note: i used C:\Users\admin\Desktop as an example you are going to have to use the file location of your file and not the one i showed)
i hope this helped and sorry fot bad english it is not my first language

topLevelComment.author: rnayabed
topLevelComment.text:
I have completed the entire tutorial and I feel a lot of topics were just omitted without properly explaining. It feels like the udemy course was taken (made by the same author), sliced at some chapters.

this is not an advanced course. Basic stuff like smart pointers were not covered. Exception handling was not properly covered. Bit wise operators and bit level operations were not even touched. Vectors were not covered. So by watching and knowing everything here, you still would be a beginner. Template functions were covered but no template classes. Threading was not covered. This is not an advanced course. probably 30-40% of c++. Other STL stuff was not covered. CMake should have its own chapter. Its not really C++, but any advanced C++ programmer should know how to use cmake.


he did not explain what constant functions are but just began using them. He did not teach us operator overloading but used overloaded << operator methods, just to name a few. You have to google these stuff yourself and learn it from other sources.

Overall a 7/10 tutorial. a 4/10 if you are really thinking this would make you an advanced c++ dev. but again, the word "advanced" is vague and can be different for a person. This is very nice and abridged and quickly sets anyone up to make stuff using C++. I am from Java Background and needed this tutorial to get me into C++.

replies.author: rnayabed
replies.text:
@mista fazal Its been 5-6 days since I last watched the video, so I may not remember but for now I cannot think of other topics. C++ itself is quite big, multithreading, mutex/semaphore/locks, etc, boost, etc.
I think this tutorial is enough for one to start writing C++ projects. you can obviously look up topics and learn them from google. You can buy a book for reference too :) I need to use Qt and QML, they provide lots of nice features so STL is not needed for me at the moment

replies.text: it's a bad idea as it'll allow using all methods of std namespace from iostream, etc. this means certain methods that you declare in your program may have the same name as a built in method, and it'll cause conflict.

topLevelComment.author: Rendzio
topLevelComment.text:
So at 7:01:28 You say that You can't do mathematic operations on data thats less than 4 bytes, however if You don't use auto type for the result and type "short int" instead it will do addition just fine and still be 2 bytes, and it doesn't convert size of the variables that are added together, it also doesn't change the size if You do the addition after declaration of a result
so You do > 
short int  result = number1 + number2;
result size shows up as 2
result = number1 + number2;
result size still shows up as 2, same goes for sizes of numbers added.

I am just learning C++ and it is genuine question not a nitpick - why does the size stay 2 bytes if You state that math operation can't be done on  variables of that size?

topLevelComment.author: Jorge Ferreira
topLevelComment.text:
Time13:53:05
The compilation error is due to the initialization, we cannot use an initial value ("Hello ") longer than the size of the array (3).
It has nothing to do with the dangers of c-string concatenation.

topLevelComment.author: Jorge Ferreira
topLevelComment.text:
Time 4:56:00
What is so difficult to understand in a remainder.
Everyone knows it since they learned division in elementary school. Decimals were only learned much latter.

topLevelComment.author: Jorge Ferreira
topLevelComment.text:
Time 4:44:50:
...
auto var3 {333u };
var3 = -22;
...
The resulting garbage stored in "var3" is not exactly garbage, it is the binary representation of (-22) in 2's complement.
Then the std::cout stream handler is converting it for printing  as an unsigned int (the variable type that resulted from the "auto").

replies.text: if c++ is your first language I would recommend that you learn something simpler like python or even lua, c++ is one of the most complicated languages and it was made in the 1980's and it's not meant for anyone who didn't have any previous experience in programming. Programming is something that takes years to learn fully, not 30 hours.

topLevelComment.author: Purplexed
topLevelComment.text:
For anyone wanting to learn C++ starting out completely new, here are the steps I recommend to take. 

1. First, I would watch the 3-4 hr tutorial by Mike on C++, take notes and completely understand it. 
2. Then come to this tutorial and go through Chapters 1-7 at your own pace. 
3. After that, take one full day or more to do each chapter because then is where things start to get harder. 


Its ok to feel overwhelmed and stuck at some points, but if you give up really easily without trying to continue, sorry but I wouldn't recommend C++ to you. You've gotta put in the effort to learn. You don't learn huge things in a day. Your journey may last for a long time spanning a year or more. It might be slow, but keep going on, its worth the hassle.

With all that being said, 
Good luck! :)

What's the point of C++ if there are no more jobs?
To get a job you need to be like from another planet, C++ is not enough. Nobody hires people who knows, at the beginner level, just c++.

replies.author: and so
replies.text:
No is hiring JavaScript who are "at the beginner level." Nor are they hiring Rust devs or are they hiring Python devs at that level. Yes, they're hiring junior developers but that is simply devs who have less than a couple years of professional experience. The rest of your experience must check out before even being considered for an interview.

The key is just like wldx said, start somewhere. Build a foundation for your knowledge and keep building on top it. This is an ever-growing field that requires constant updates of your knowledge.

topLevelComment.text: When you're assigning a negative value to an unsigned int, it doesn't get a 'garbage' value. The negative int will be written in memory in binary, and then the same binary will be read as an unsigned int.

topLevelComment.author: Jared Lee
topLevelComment.text: i do appreciate this video I've been following this video but can someone explain why he mentions all of these other compliers when the best one he mentioned is Microsoft visual studio is literally an all in one compiler and debugger and works better that any other complier he mentioned its funny msvs is the program we are using yet wasting time with other compilers has any one one else noticed that? couldn't we just use the one program we are already using to write code to also use its other function to compile just curious there is no reason to try mess with other compilers when you are using an all in one program

replies.author: and so
replies.text: @Sceptic Sorry, I was mostly addressing Jared's question. I believe the compilers and debuggers aren't as crucial during the learning phase. The device I'm using a small form laptop with less than 250GB of storage. As such, I'm getting along just fine with an online compiler (the precision is off but that's the only issue I've encountered after 25 hours of following along). Also note that most of the folks over at Silicon valley prefer Xcode anyways so I wouldn't get too hung on the IDE choice so early in your journey.

replies.author: Sceptic
replies.text: @and so Your explanation is good, my confusion is why use VSC over Visual studio community for example? It is very complicated to debug and run a simple code, specially for beginners, in VSC, you have to download huge compilers, work with json files to configure everything,.. etc.

replies.author: and so
replies.text: Honestly it can boil to preference but do keep in mind that while all compile serve virtually the same purpose, no compiler is 1:1. Some compilers cut certain corners here and other compilers cut certain corners there. Most programmers prefer Cpp over others due to optimization and if that is your primary objective, you have to shop around for the compiler that best suit your needs. If optimization isn't that important and MSVC is the most convenient tool at your disposal, then by all means, go for it. It's like an army swiss knife and a switch blade, the effectiveness (and preference) of the tool depends entirely upon the user and the task at hand. I feel Daniel outlined this when he went over Compiler Explorer - it compares the translated machine code produced by the specified compilers.

topLevelComment.author: and so
topLevelComment.text:
Please understand that while Cppreference is a good resource, it is by no means an official reference for documentation. Cpp is a standard and not a product so there is no official documentation.
ISO publishes documentation for major updates but the committee themselves have stated that there are better easier to read references out there. The scope of their documentation isn't necessarily to teach about the features and functionalities but to inform.

replies.author: Nors2Ka
replies.text:
@Elusive What are you even actually talking about? You think I'm advocating for namespacing std::? Like, you have to be deliberately reading what I wrote wrongly.

I'm saying that an introduction shouldn't use *any* libraries so you could see what is *actually* going on and not do some glorified scripting, for which you should just use a scripting language since you're not really programming at that point.

replies.author: Elusive
replies.text: @Nors2Ka std is better than having a bunch of memory wasted from using the name space. I'd rather have an optimized program than some 200gb game that's full of bugs and programs with the engine. The point is you start here then move onto books where you can learn more depending on what you want to do.

replies.author: Nors2Ka
replies.text:
@Mustafa Türk With anything that doesn't start by littering your program with STD's. Not to mention that some things explained in this video are straight up wrong.

A very good example is Casey Muratori's "Intro to C on Windows" series, which is admittedly quite old now, but since programming is as it ever was, the series remains valid in many more ways than this video from year 2022. It does miss a few absolute beginner things, since the series wasn't actually purpose made for education purposes, but there's nothing you can't infer if you're an astute observer.

replies.author: REDMI
replies.text:
A string of n integers is given, representing the packets sent, and another string with n - m integers, representing the packets that have successfully reached you.

The items in the second row will NOT be in the same order as those in the first. However, if there are several packages with the same value, they end up in the order of the positions in the original string.

In addition, all values ​​in the second string are in the first. Identify the missing elements, taking into account that they are not necessarily in consecutive positions in the first row.

Input data
On the first line you will find the numbers n and m, separated by a space, and on the next two lines the elements of the two strings.

Output data
The program will display on the screen, in the order in which they appear in the first row, separated by a space, the m missing items in the second row
Example :
7 3
12 34 45 29 100 87 32
100 87 12 34 

Output data :
45 29 32

topLevelComment.author: boi dapz
topLevelComment.text:
EXERCISE
A student is identified by the following elements:
 The registration number of the student;
 The name of the student;
 Date of birth of the student;
 Place of birth of the student;
 Department of the student;
 The level of studies;
 The option of the student;
 The gender of the student;
 List of subjects done by the student with associated credit values and marks;
 Telephone number of the student;
1. Propose a class called Student with these components including getters and setters for each 
member data to represent a student.
2. Propose a data structure to be used to store a total of 500 students. 
3. Give the declaration and definition of the different constructors of the class Student:
a) It takes two parameters assigned respectively to the registration number and the name. 
The gender by default is assigned as male. 
b) It takes three parameters to be assigned to the registration number, the name and the 
Telephone number of the student respectively.
c) It takes as parameters The registration number, name, date of birth, place of birth, 
Department, level of studies, option of the student, gender, subjects done by the student 
with associated credit values and telephone number of the student 
to be assigned to the corresponding member data.
4. Add a method called registration that will be used to register a new student. displays the 
information of a Student.
5. Add a method called display that displays all the information of a registered Student.
6. Add a member function called average that will evaluate and return the average of a 
registered student.
7. Add a member function called search that uses the registration number of the student and 
returns all his information it the Student is registered.
4. Add a member function called grade that takes in the average of a student and returns his 
corresponding grade based on the following criteria.
Range of the average grade
average<10 FAILED
10<average<12 Fairly Good
12<average<14 Good
14<average<16 Very Good
16<average Excellent
5. Give a subclass of the above class student which includes the following elements 
 Year of admission
 Street of residence
 hobby

topLevelComment.author: BlaXeon
topLevelComment.text:
Will update with questions and queries:

4:10:10 why does narrowing conversion give consistently the same garbage numbers? eg 192400023 > 192400016

6:24:56 Just want to point out that setting bases for negative numbers doesn't actually work.

7:45:36 Ternary Operators are really cool. 😎

9:26:00 Why do we use "auto" as type declaration in the for loop? Is it because the type of i is dependent on the type of what the array is?

10:19:00 Just wondering when using pointers on char is ever useful? Like it seems so dangerous and also unusable. Is it better than declaring a character array?
> Follow up: Can you also not change the address of a pointer with const char? Is the only way to declare a character pointer like - const char * message{" "};   ?
> It gives me errors like "a value of type "char (*)[9]" cannot be used to initialise an entity of type "char *".

11:23:53 Was about to say making p_number8 = nullptr; didn't work. Then I had another look and it turns out I used ==. 😅

13:12:23 Just a note: LHS RHS usually refers to "left hand side" "right hand side".

13:39:30 Ok sure, the mistake is clear. So the reason not to just have str = std::strchr(str,target) is to avoid overwriting the original pointer?  If you don't care about doing that, what's the problem??

14:16:44 It seems as if we've skipped ahead. Do we have to declare the function as a variable before writing the definition or was this just proving a point?
> Explained at 15:01:50 👍

16:08:03 This idea seems to keep cropping up, it seems as if references are always more preferred to pointers since they effectively have the same function. Why is this (is it to do with memory management?) and what are some specific use cases where you'd want to use pointers over references, or where'd you'd specifically need to use either a pointer or a reference?

16:48:00 Unsure about how std::string_view differs from std::string?

18:08:21 Hmm don't know how to set up debugging, was not taught in this version of the course. 🙁
>>Update, roughly followed the instructions from the visual studio code website and created a launch.json file and added it to my template code.

19:24:23 Hoping to find out why you would use any one of these concept structures over another, and also how this works with overloading. I'm sure this will get touched on. Also, is this the only usecase for concepts or do they crop up elsewhere?

20:00:41 Do we need to include both portions of the concept with the nested concept? e.g. "requres sizeof(T) <= 4" AND "sizeof(T) <= 4". Or can we just have the requires by itself. Or is it like, checks first and then using that check it can satisfy the requires part??

22:04:41 He's not wrong, destructors are confusing...
> I assume we only need a destructor for when there's a pointer in our class variables?

22:33:13 Really cool concept but definitely gonna have to go over this again. Why does it always get confusing when pointers are involved?

23:08:42 Not super related to the current topic, but I wonder if you ever make header files just solely full of header files, and call that in the main function? If that would limit the amount of failed code because of header files being called multiple times or something like that. Or if that is never considered and not deemed an issue. Or maybe even just for neatness and organisation.

25:47:14 Ok so what I find cool about this is that you can make a person object from a engineer object e.g. Person person1(eng1); I don't know how useful that is but it seems pretty neat to me.
>Oh cool, this is more or less this slicing thing explained at 27:20:00

27:47:21 Ok I don't understand. The reasoning to put "override" in for if you made a typo doesn't make any sense. There must be a better reason for this other than that?????? Especially since this is just more typing so more security for typos doesn't really track.

28:07:55 Uhhh Daniel, Dogs aren't felines. Just saying....

29:10:06 Yep this one is breaking my mind. I might have to just rewatch all of this chapter because I'm not sure I really understand static/dynamic binding. And then so setting up a base pointer to a derived class, you get the static values called? I don't really understand this at all I guess.
>So does this still apply when you set up arrays with these elements?
>I suppose this is why he recommends not using these. SO CONFUSING.
>Presumably you can't get 21 with some combination of these. i.e. use default parameters from derived and method from base.

30:50:45 Since an interface is an abstract class, can you have another abstract class inherit it? It wont need to override the pure virtual method will it?


BIG THANKS TO DANIEL FOR TEACHING ME C++!!!!  Now to try some libraries. Any recommendations? Want to have a look into OpenCV..

topLevelComment.author: Oanh Mai
topLevelComment.text:
Last chance to join us at a FREE live virtual hands-on workshop - Advanced SYCL Concepts for Heterogenous Computing!
https://software.seek.intel.com/oneapi-advancedSYCLconcepts 
Learn and practice the advanced concepts and features of SYCL with live sample code on Intel DevCloud. At the end of this workshop, you will be able to efficiently write SYCL code for heterogenous computing. Be one of the first programmers at the forefront of this compelling and important new development that elevates computing to a new level.
In this workshop, Intel Developer Evangelist Rakshith Krishnappa will cover some advanced concepts in SYCL programming for heterogenous computing. Topics include:
1) Learn pointer-based memory management for heterogenous computing using Unified Shared Memory.
2) Understand implicit and explicit way of moving memory using Unified Shared Memory and also handling data dependency between kernel executions.
3) Understand advantages of using Subgroups in SYCL programming.
4) Take advantage of Subgroup group algorithms and understand how Subgroup Shuffle operations can avoid explicit memory operations
5) Use SYCL reduction to simplify reduction with parallel kernels
6) Take advantages reduce function to do reduction at sub_group and work_group level
We look forward to seeing you there.

topLevelComment.author: Faredj fouiny
topLevelComment.text:
Please can you help me to realize this program please:
 Write a C program that implements a question-and-answer game.
 The program will start by asking the user if they want to play a game.  If the answer
 of the user is negative the program will end.  If the user's response is positive, the
 program will ask a series of questions.
 For each question, three possible answers are offered.  The user will respond to
 different questions by choosing the number of the correct answer.  The program will then evaluate
 the user's answer in order to inform him if it is correct or not.
 At the end of the game, the program will display to the user:
 • The number of correct answers.
 • The number of games played.
 • His maximum score.
 It will then offer the user to play a new game or quit the game.

topLevelComment.author: ChiefSittingStill
topLevelComment.text:
I don't want to be too picky about the pronunciation, as your English is excellent; far better than my speaking of any other tongue than my native English 😅But as you've helped me so much with your C++ language expertise, it seems fair to help you a bit with my English language 'expertise' on some of the words that did jar a bit as you were saying them:

paradigm - pronounce it 'pa-ra-dime'
readable - pronounce it 'ree-da-bull' (not 'rid-da-bull')
crow - 'croh' 
oval - same as crow, say it with an oh sound; so it's 'oh-val' rather than 'ov-al'
word - pronounce it like 'whirred' rather than 'whirled' (there's no 'l' in it)

Hope that helps 🙂

So should take me around 15 days, however I plan on increasing the amount of hours done during friday through sunday to around 5 hours. I want to learn unreal engine after this so I can build some good applications and games this year for my portfolio on github.

topLevelComment.author: Janmajay Kumar
topLevelComment.text: I could not stop myself from commenting a third time. This whole lecture is worth 1000 hours digging into books for a person who is stranded in c++.  Almost all teachers of c++ try to skip ''why' while they're teaching c++ the first time. This is not healthy as much as I can say as a novice. A bare minimum answer to why things happening is necessary to start learning c++. Because c++ is not the language that is sitting on the well-furnished sofa. This is a language close to the machine, so hiding its ugliness by bypassing the answer to why is an extremely bad habit and terribly confusing. These are reasons which make this lecture a great among lot on Youtube Careful explanation with extensive examples and supplying the bare minimum exposition of how do machines understand. I hope people who want to start c++ will benefit a lot from this lecture. However, one more thing you can do is you can suggest some good web page or book which offers lots of exercise problems for practice in the spirit of your lecture. I will be grateful to you.

topLevelComment.author: Shadowwand
topLevelComment.text:
I am completely awed by the mere existence of this video.

For 1, I had believed 10 Hrs was the maximum limit to a video on YouTube.

For 2, those other videos are usually repeated loops of footage, as in not unique footage for the entire length.

But then when I saw the Subject Matter of the video, I knew exactly what sort of subject would put in the effort to research and produce a 30+ hour free of charge on the internet video teaching a subject: Introduction to Computer Sciences.

No other group respects and values making ideas freely available for others to look at, learn from and promote the best products through open Ness and honesty.

I'm not even thay serious a programmer, I deal mainly in Lua for architectural control Processors. 

But seeing that this community came together to even have the audacity to not merely dream of making this video where timecode measures days, but to actually produce it and upload it to the internet.

I can't even fathom the effort it took to do that. I feel like the designers of the death star did not put in nearly as much effort as you did.

And for that alone, I feel compelled to save this video, and try to learn what you were teaching.

Because you thought it was worth that much effort to teach me for free.

I just got stuck at compiling the first program and this is how I made the program compile for me in Linux.

g++ -std=c++20 first.cpp -o first
./first

The commands given above makes sure it uses the C++ 20 for compilation. (My g++ version is g++ (GCC) 11.1.0)

I was using a simple text editor for the first program 🙂

replies.author: C B
replies.text: Very good question... I hate to put a downer on this because it is an amazing free tutorial, but as an experienced former C++ dev, I would say forget C++, learn Rust or Golang or Python instead! Learn Rust if you want to do low-level programming for operating systems, or game development; Golang if you want to do very fast web backends; and Python if you want to do web programming, data science or machine learning.

replies.author: daemon
replies.text: Exactly, besides it only teaches c++ syntax which is of no use without teaching computational thinking, algorithms and giving opportunities to practice. Skimmed through the entire thing and it's just the typical low value tutorial that only goes 0.1% into every subject and at the end of which the student is just as clueless as he was when he went in plus a few extra programming keywords. I mean it's free so you can't complain but it doesn't make it any less of a suboptimal way of going about learning programming.

topLevelComment.author: Seasoned Veteran
topLevelComment.text: Thank you so much for taking the time to do this tutorial, could only imagine how much time and effort it took to get this done. I have only been able to find the entry-level information on C++ that went through pretty much what everyone else does. The more advanced topics are what I need to get my certificate and so far this is the closest I have come to find a comprehensive course. There was one by a woman on YouTube that runs 10 hours and is fantastic however it was lacking advanced topics.

replies.author: Apollyon, King of the Locusts
replies.text: MyCodeSchool channel has a lengthy (but a bit old) course about data structures in C/C++ which is an advanced theoretical topic and seems to be omitted here. Also, they have a course about recursive functions (needed in sort and search functions) and "Big O" notation (to estimate the the time and space complexity of your algorithms) which are also not present here.

replies.author: Ronald Maffei de Lavor
replies.text:
Aqui estão 4 poderosas orações que você pode rezar pelas almas do purgatório, que precisam muito delas:

1) Oração de Santa Gertrudes
Eterno Pai, Ofereço-Vos o Preciosíssimo Sangue de Vosso Divino Filho Jesus, em união com todas as Missas que hoje são celebradas em todo o mundo; por todas as Santas almas do purgatório, pelos pecadores de todos os lugares, pelos pecadores de toda a Igreja, pelos de minha casa e de meus vizinhos. Amém.

2) Oração para ter um coração misericordioso para com os outros de Santa Faustina.

Ó Jesus, compreendo que a Vossa misericórdia é inexprimível. Por isso Vos suplico: tornai o meu coração tão grande que possa conter as necessidades de todas as almas que vivem na face da terra. Ó Jesus, o meu amor vai além do mundo, estende-se até às almas que sofrem no purgatório; também por elas quero praticar misericórdia através de orações que possuem indulgências. A misericórdia de Deus é sempre insondável e
Inesgotável, como é insondável o próprio Deus. Ainda que eu me valesse das palavras mais veementes para expressar essa misericórdia de Deus, tudo isso nada seria em comparação com o que ela é na realidade. Ó Jesus, fazei o meu coração sensível a cada sofrimento do meu próximo, seja da alma ou do corpo. Ó meu
Jesus, sei que Vós procedeis conosco como nós procedemos com o próximo.
Meu Jesus, fazei o meu coração semelhante ao Vosso misericordioso Coração. Jesus, ajudai-me a passar pela vida fazendo o
Bem a todos…
Amém.
Fonte: Diário de Santa Faustina, II, #132

3) Oração do Descanso eterno:

Dai-lhes Senhor o descanso eterno.
E que a luz perpétua os ilumine. Descansem em paz.
Pai Misericordioso eu vos ofereço o sangue precioso de Nosso Senhor Jesus Cristo para alívio das almas sofredoras que ainda padecem no purgatório. Amém.

4) Ladainha pelas almas do Purgatório:

Deus onipotente, Pai de bondade e de misericórdia, tende piedade das benditas almas do purgatório e ajudai a meus queridos pais e antepassados.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai a meus irmãos e parentes.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai a todos meus benfeitores espirituais e temporais.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos que tem sido meus amigos e empregados.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai a quantos devo amar e orar.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai a quantos tive prejudicado e ferido.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos que tiveram faltado contra mim.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aqueles a quem professais predileção.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos que estão mais próximos a união convosco.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos que vos desejam mais ardentemente.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos que sofrem mais.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos que estão mais longe de sua liberação.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos que menos auxílios recebem.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos que mais méritos tem pela Igreja.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos que foram ricos aqui, e ali são os mais pobres.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos poderosos, que agora são como servos.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos cegos que agora reconhecem sua cegueira.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos vaidosos que desperdiçaram seu tempo.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos pobres que não buscaram as riquezas divinas.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos tíbios que muito pouca oração tem feito.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos presunçosos que tem descuidado de tantas obras boas.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos de pouca fé que descuidaram dos Santos Sacramentos.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos reincidentes que apenas por um milagre da graça se tem salvado.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos pais que não vigiaram bem a seus filhos.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos superiores pouco atentos a salvação de seus súditos.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos pobres homens, que quase apenas se preocuparam do dinheiro e do prazer.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos de espírito mundano que não aproveitaram suas riquezas ou talentos para o céu.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos néscios, que viram morrer a tantos não se lembrando de sua própria morte.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos que não dispuseram a tempo de sua casa, estando completamente desprevenidos para a viagem mais importante.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos que julgais mais severamente, quanto mais lhes foi confiado.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos pontífices, reis e príncipes.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos bispos e seus conselheiros.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai a meus mestres e pastores de almas.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos finados sacerdotes desta diocese.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos sacerdotes e religiosos da Igreja católica.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos defensores da santa fé.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos caídos nos campos de batalha.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos sepultados nos mares.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos mortos repentinamente.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Ajudai aos falecidos sem receber os Santos Sacramentos.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Dai-lhes, Senhor, a todas as almas o descanso eterno.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! E fazei brilhar sobre elas vossa eterna luz.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Que em paz descansem.

Jesus meu, misericórdia! Amém.
